Section: [[CT Term 1 Topic 1 (Root)]]
## Silicon Chips 

- CPU is an integrated circuit 
    
    - Transistors 
        
    - Connected by microscopic wires 
        
- Typically manufacture hundreds of copies for error checking 
    

Multi-core processor 

- Independent cores manufactured on the same IC 
    
- Sharing memory and other resources 
    
- Operations carried out in parallel 
    
- Requires a lower clock speed to have the same processing power as single-core 
    
- Can often reduce power consumption and heating 
    

1.1.4 - Moore's Law 

- Transistor capacity doubles every 18-24 months (nearly) 
    
    - Estimation of a long-term trend 
        
- Will eventually reach a fundamental barrier (the size of atoms) 
    

1.1.5 - Gates 

- Transistors form logic gates 
    
    - Take binary inputs and produce binary outputs 
        
- NAND can form NOT, AND, and OR 
    
    - Where NAND is - 
        
    - AND = ( A - B ) - ( A – B ) 
        
    - OR = ( A – A ) - ( B – B ) 
        
    - NOT = A – A 
        

1.1.6 - A Binary World 

- Half adders 
    
    - Inputs are two bits 
        
    - Outputs the sum of the two bits and the associated carry 
        

![Fig. 3: a half-adder.](data:image/png;base64,)

- S = ( x + y ) . !( x . y ) = x XOR y 
    
- C =  x . Y 
    

- Full adders 
    
    - Inputs are x, y and c (c is a carry) 
        
    - Outputs the Boolean sum and a new carry (d) 
        
    - D is a 1 if and only if at least 2 inputs are 1 
        

![Fig. 4: a full-adder.](data:image/png;base64,)

- Can be combined to add 2 n-bit numbers 
    

![孰 circuit add wo a-bit numbers.](data:image/png;base64,)

1.1.7 - Pentium 4 processor microarchitecture 

- Datapath 
    
    - Performs data processing operations 
        
    - Includes the ALU and registers 
        
- Control 
    
    - Manages operations of the datapath, memory and I/O devices 
        
- Cache 
    
    - Small, fast, expensive memory located on-chip 
        
    - Stores regularly accessed data (data caches) or instructions (instruction caches) 
        
    - Hierarchical structure 
        
        - Level 1 cache is static RAM built into the CPU 
            
        - Level 2 cache is static RAM either into the CPU or a short distance away 
            

1.1.8 - Architecture 

- Von Neumann 
    
    - Stored program and data held in same memory 
        
    - Allows for self-modifying programs 
        
    - Bottleneck as data transfer rate between CPU and memory is limited 
        
    - CPU is often idling 
        
- Harvard 
    
    - Memory split into data and instructions, each with dedicated busses 
        
    - Lessens bottleneck 
        

1.1.9 - Memory 

- Each memory location has an address and one byte of storage 
    
- Larger words formed using batches of bytes 
    
    - Word is the amount of data handled by the processor in one unit, word size determined by the architecture 
        
- Buses 
    
    - Series of parallel wires that allows communication between components 
        
    - Number of wires is width 
        
    - Unique signals = 2^width 
        
    - Address bus holds addresses of locations in memory, width determines size of addressable memory 
        
    - Data bus carries content of memory locations  
        
    - Control bus transfers information between the CPU and other devices such as read/write signals 
        

1.1.10 - Other Types of Memory 

- Hard disk 
    
    - Rapidly rotated disks with a read/write head 
        
- RAM 
    
    - Dynamic RAM uses transistor capacitor combos to store bits of data 
        
    - Cheap but needs to be refreshed + slow (capacitors leak) 
        
    - Static RAM is stored using flip-flops 
        
    - Fast and stable but larger 
        

1.1.11 - Fetch, Decode, Fetch, Execute 

- Instruction fetch 
    
    - PC value taken by address bus to memory 
        
    - Memory returns the instruction at that address 
        
    - Stored on instruction registers within CPU 
        
- Instruction decode 
    
    - Instruction decoded by internal logic 
        
    - Provides control signals that instructs the ALU what is needed to execute the instruction 
        
    - Program counter incremented by word-size 
        
- Operand Fetch 
    
    - Instruction registers provide address of data to be processed to address bus 
        
    - Memory returns the operand data to the CPU via data bus 
        
- Execute Instruction 
    
    - With the data and instruction, the ALU carries out the instruction on the operand 
        
    - This can involve updating the PC or using the accumulator or writing back into memory
